awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Cooperative Small-Molecule Activation by Ambiphilic Pincer-Type Complexes Featuring Metal/Main-Group Bonds
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Matthew T. Whited of Carleton College works with a research group of undergraduate students to investigate the preparation and reactivity of new complexes featuring transition metal/main-group bonds with acidic and basic sites. In these systems an electron-rich transition metal works synergistically with an electron-poor main-group to facilitate difficult reactions. This allows the development of new selective transformations of industrially and environmentally important molecules such as carbon dioxide and hydrocarbons. This project is developing earth abundant metal catalysts to convert carbon dioxide into chemical feedstocks. This is important contribution to achieving sustainability. As such the project contributes to the Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering, and Materials (SusChEM) effort. Professor Whited is also developing course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) at Carleton College and working with an outreach program to bring local high-school students into Carleton College chemistry laboratories.

This project seeks to understand and develop reactions around late-metal/main-group interactions using complexes featuring constrained metal-silicon single and multiple bonds as prototypes. In order to constrain the metal-silicon linkage, the silyl group is tethered into an easily modified pincer-type ligand. The "electronic frustration" resulting from the disparity between electron-rich late metals and electropositive silicon, combined with the kinetic lability of bonds to each, allows the development of a cooperative approach to strong-bond activation with applications in catalytic hydrocarbon oxidation and carbon dioxide reduction. Spectroscopic and reactivity studies of metal/silicon systems motivate the expansion of this research to include pincers with boryl and carbyl/carbene donors as well as to catalysis with earth-abundant metals. The project provides a training ground for undergraduate researchers and supports the expansion of both college- and high-school education efforts related to Dr. Whited's interests in inorganic synthesis and X-ray crystallography.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new approaches to utilizing bonds between transition metals and metalloids (especially silicon) to promote cooperative chemical reactions, with a special focus on molecules that are abundant and/or toxic, such as carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide. This research was driven by Carleton College undergraduates, leading to significant mentoring and education opportunities for undergraduate students, and further materials were developed to engage Carleton undergraduates through the PI’s teaching labs and outreach to Northfield High School students.

The fundamental goal of this research project was to introduce polarized metal/silicon bonds as ambiphilic scaffolds for transformation of small molecules. This goal was pursued by stabilizing the reactive metal/silicon linkages with a rigid organometallic “pincer-type” framework. Synthetic studies showed that modification of the silicon center with a variety of groups could dramatically affect resulting reactivity, and strongly electrophilic silicon centers were found to enable the activation of carbon dioxide (weakening or breaking the strong C=O bond by several different mechanisms, all relying on oxygen coordination to silicon) and non-polar molecules such as ethylene, steps that show high promise in the development of catalytic reactions of abundant feedstocks. Subsequent development of these complexes allowed the discovery of a novel mechanistic route for producing isocyanates through silicon/cobalt cooperative nitrene/CO coupling. Mechanistic studies of this catalytic process introduced the idea that metals and electrophilic metalloids with orthogonal binding preferences may be combined to avoid catalyst poisoning in coupling reactions involving CO and other strong ligands. In all cases, synthetic and mechanistic studies were accompanied by computational analysis of structure and mechanism to illuminate the factors governing metal/silicon cooperative reactivity. Broader impacts of this research include the development of new mechanistic approaches to transition-metal catalysis that can be utilized for abundant chemical feedstocks (e.g., carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, ethylene) as well as training 30 undergraduate students in the scientific research process through summer- and academic-year research in the PI’s laboratory.

The education plan associated with this proposal focused on three interrelated areas: (a) mentoring undergraduate students in the PI’s laboratory; (b) expanding and assessing efforts by the PI in course-based chemistry research; and (c) bringing Northfield High School students to Carleton to participate in organic and inorganic lab experiments. Efforts in course-based research enabled the creation of a new course at Carleton and an extensive set of rubrics for formative and summative evaluation of students in course-based research settings, which are publicly available: https://research.mwhited.sites.carleton.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Rubric-items-for-student-evaluation-for-posting.pdf. Expansion of course-based research in an upper-level inorganic teaching laboratory at Carleton engaged an additional 28 students, many of whom were co-authors on crystallographic reports generated through the laboratory.


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Matthew T Whited
